Speaker: station agent
Dialogue: Expectin' someone?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I guess not. Where's the stagecoach office?

Speaker: station agent
Dialogue: Back of the depot.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: -- makes you the most aggravatin' female as ever I had a despise fer -- I've got a good notion to pizen you -- an' what's more --

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Fooled myself, too.

Speaker: stage agent
Dialogue: Howdy.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: That the stage for Santa Inez?

Speaker: stage agent
Dialogue: Leaving any minute.

Speaker: stage agent
Dialogue: Santa Inez -- seventeen-fifty --  Name?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Rocklin.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Mind if I ride alongside the driver?

Speaker: stage agent
Dialogue: It's all right with me -- if it's all right with Dave -- He's mad -- His last trip -- Had a row with Harolday, the boss -- Old-timer, Dave -- an' a grumpy old cuss.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I like grumpy old cusses -- Hope to live long enough to be one.

Speaker: stage agent
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: stage agent
Dialogue: Here's your mail, Dave --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: -- and a passenger.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Mind if I ride up here?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Where's them wimmen?

Speaker: stage agent
Dialogue: Up at the hotel.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Ain't it?

Speaker: stage agent
Dialogue: You can pick 'em up there -- it's only up the street --

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: On'y up the street -- an' they cain't walk it -- What's the matter -- don't Easterners have laigs like other folks?

Speaker: stage agent
Dialogue: Hold tight when you git in the mountains, mister -- When he gits riled you can hear the passengers prayin' for miles.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Whar's them wimmen? -- They waitin' for you to carry 'em out?

Speaker: saddler
Dialogue: Dave -- Dave -- tell Arly Harolday her saddle ain't ready yet, will ya?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: I ain't tellin' that crazy female nothin' -- Last time I seen her she threatened to rip the hide off'n me and bat me dizzy with it.

Speaker: saddler
Dialogue: Mister -- will you tell the Agent at Santa Inez to tell Miss Harolday her saddle ain't ready yet?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I'll say that.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: By next year, madam, we expect to have a bathtub on each floor.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Now don't drop it --

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: At your age you'd best not be lifting things so heavy.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Clara!

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Staring as though you'd never seen a man before.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Try to hold him down or he'll scare the women to death.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I never feel sorry for anything that happens to a woman.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Well, I hope you have a nice trip, ladies.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: I hope we get there -- wouldn't surprise me if we didn't.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Wait till I get you on the road, you old buzzard, you'll be surprised all right.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: I wonder why a young feller who don't have to wants to come into this God danged country?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Say -- did you mean what you said back there about wimmen?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Every word of it.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Then you're smarter than most.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Maybe I seen more of 'em than most.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: All the same...

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: All the same -- what?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Take a slug.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Whiskey and wimmen -- ever think how much alike they are? Both fool you, but you never figger out how to do without 'em.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Take another.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Not just yet.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Here's to her.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: The next one that fools you.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Mighty rough stretch along here.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Like me to speel you a while?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Nope. I've had a few snorts but that don't make no difference. Leas'ways, never has...  Don't ever git wore out, and useless, like me.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Who're them as say you are?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Harolday, for one. Oh, I ain't belly- aching. Reckon he's entitled to his opinion. But him and me never did see eye to eye.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: What's wrong?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: It's constitootional, I reckon. Like that step-daughter of his is crazy -- he's too sane. Believes In law and order.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: What's wrong with law and order?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Depends on who's a-dishin' it out. Never was good at takin' orders meself. As for the law -- well, you'll soon find out what that means 'round these parts.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Driver? Driver, what's the matter?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Nothin'. Restin' hosses. Git out and stretch yore laigs if you want.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Resting horses? What for? I can see with my own eyes it's downhill.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: You in such an all-fired hurry, lady?

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Certainly, we are in a hurry.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Well -- we'll hurry some.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Now what's the matter. Why are we stopping again?

Speaker: pablo
Dialogue: Buenas noches, senor.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Buenas noches, amigo.

Speaker: pablo
Dialogue: Ha llegado anticipademente, senor.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Tuvimos suerte en haber llegado.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: We stop here.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Why do we stop here?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: If you wanta eat and stretch yore laigs.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Will you please stop referring to my legs!

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: You got some, ain't you?

Speaker: zeke
Dialogue: Dave!

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Why, Zeke, you two-legged old coot!

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Whar you been all these months?

Speaker: zeke
Dialogue: Up in the hills workin' my way down the biggest hole you ever seed.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Good -- What's at the bottom of it?

Speaker: zeke
Dialogue: Nothin'!

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: What, again!!

Speaker: stan
Dialogue: Good evening, ladies. How about something to eat?

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Well -- if it won't take too long.

Speaker: stan
Dialogue: This way, ladies.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Yep -- this is my last trip.

Speaker: zeke
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Old Harolday won't take back what he said.

Speaker: zeke
Dialogue: What'd he say?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: "You're fired."

Speaker: stan
Dialogue: There you are, folks. Dig in and help y'rselves.

Speaker: stan
Dialogue: Supper, Dave?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: I'm drinkin' mine. Set 'em up.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Auntie --

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: With my dyspepsia? Do you want to kill me?

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Aren't you going to have any supper?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Reckon so.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Young man, that driver's had all the liquor he can take.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Has he?

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: You know he has. You're not a complete fool, are you?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Frequently.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: The rudeness of people in these parts is appalling!

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: Doin' yourself well these days, Stan.

Speaker: stan
Dialogue: A friend of mine was by an' sold me a quarter of beef.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: The same friend as sold you that hide Bob, here, found stashed in your barn yesterday?

Speaker: stan
Dialogue: Hide -- What hide?

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: The one that might send you to the penitentiary.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: What did you do with it, Stan?

Speaker: stan
Dialogue: I never had no hide stashed --

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: I saw it yesterday under the hay.

Speaker: stan
Dialogue: Then it must still be there.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: No it ain't -- we looked -- Where is it?

Speaker: stan
Dialogue: I tell ya --

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: What is all this?

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Afternoon ma'am. Miz Caldwell ain't it?

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: No -- Martin -- Miss Martin -- This is Miss Caldwell.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Glad to know you, miss -- Been expectin' you at Santa Inez. I'm Sheriff Jackson. Any relation of Red Caldwell's a friend of mine.

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: You're sure gonna brighten things up considerable around the K.C. Ranch.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: What's going on with him?

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Just a little matter of the law.

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: Rustlin'.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Wrestling?

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: Rustlin' -- cattle stealin'.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Oh -- a thief --

Speaker: stan
Dialogue: I tell ya I never --

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: Save it --

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Matter of fact -- Bob, here, says that the hide he saw yesterday had the K.C. brand on it.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Oh -- hmmm -- well, what do you intend doing about it?

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: Law's pretty harsh 'round here on cattle thieves.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Course, we don't want to make a mistake with an old-timer, but --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: How about the owner of that beef -- mightn't he have somethin' to say about it?

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Meanin'?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Red Caldwell -- he's the owner of the K.C., ain't he?

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: You're 'way behind the herd, mister -- Red Caldwell died three weeks ago.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Was murdered, you mean.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: That's right -- shot in the back -- not far from here.

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: Maybe he was gettin' on to things about the cattle that's been missin' from the K.C. lately.

Speaker: stan
Dialogue: I tell ya I ain't never had any hide --

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: Well, you got beef --

Speaker: stan
Dialogue: Yes -- an' I got a bill of sale fer it, too.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: S'pose you let me see that bill of sale.

Speaker: stan
Dialogue: It's right out here.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Like I said -- I wouldn't want to make a mistake with an ole-timer.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: She ain't got no laigs.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Hold your tongue.  And you -- stop staring as if we were monsters.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Where's Stan? We got to have another drink.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: He's outside tryin' to explain away a hide.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Eh?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Seems we're eatin' stolen beef.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Somebody's loco. Stan might have given house-room to bit o' dead beef, but he'd never be fool enough to leave the hide lyin' around.  How 'bout it, Zeke?

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: That's the way it is, Dave.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Oh -- it's you.

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: That's right -- your old pal Bob Clews.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Git away from me -- you two-timin' horse thief.

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: Them's fightin' words, pardner.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Hey, Stan -- don't let 'em hang nothin' on you, you ain't done. They're just a couple of fourflushers -- the pair of 'em, everybody knows that.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Crazy drunk.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Mebbe I am drunk -- mebbe that's why I'm tellin' the truth -- I'm drunk an' I'll say what I think -- I'll say what I know.

Speaker: zeke
Dialogue: So will -- I --

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Don't act up this ways, Dave -- They's women watchin'.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Git your hands off me --

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: What he needs is a short lay-down.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I'll lend a hand.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Careful now -- don't hurt him.

Speaker: stan
Dialogue: -- kinda winded him.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Good thing you saved it.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: zeke
Dialogue: Musta been dreamin' -- Thought I was sittin' on a pot of gold.

Speaker: stan
Dialogue: There ain't no gold here.

Speaker: zeke
Dialogue: There ain't even a pot.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: How is he?

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Went to sleep soon's we laid him down.  Sorry to have a ruckus in front of you ladies. Dave's an ornery old cuss when he gets goin' -- No shape to drive on, I'm afraid.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Hmmm --

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Don't worry, ma'am. Bob, here, 'll take you on in -- knows every inch of the road -- Don't you?

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: You bet.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I'm drivin'.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: But if anything was to happen to the ladies, I'd feel -- to blame.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Don't.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: You ladies want he should drive?

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: I'll be more'n glad to accommodate you --

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: He's going with us anyway -- he may as well drive.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Anything you say, ma'am.

Speaker: mexican
Dialogue: Venga con migo, senor.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Did they do it?

Speaker: mexican
Dialogue: Si, senor. They hit him with a pistola.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: His friends, eh?

Speaker: stableman
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Bumped his head.

Speaker: stableman
Dialogue: Where -- on Iron Mountain?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Where's the best chance of a cheap room?

Speaker: stableman
Dialogue: There's Cap's place across the Street -- the Sun-Up Saloon.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I'll pick that up later.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: This isn't the hotel.

Speaker: stableman
Dialogue: No'm, lady. Hotel's up the street a piece.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Are we expected to carry our bags at this time of night?

Speaker: stableman
Dialogue: Want to drive 'em on up?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Here -- catch aholt.

Speaker: cap
Dialogue: Hey Doc!

Speaker: cap's voice
Dialogue: Customer --

Speaker: doc riding
Dialogue: Take my hand, Sammy.

Speaker: doc riding
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Bumped his head.

Speaker: doc riding
Dialogue: Better get him upstairs.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Okay. You can book me a room, too.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: No laigs.

Speaker: doc riding
Dialogue: He'll be all right in the morning.

Speaker: doc riding
Dialogue: How about a snort?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Don't mind if I do.

Speaker: cap
Dialogue: Will he make it?

Speaker: doc riding
Dialogue: Sure he'll make it. Can't kill off a salty old hairpin like Dave that easy.

Speaker: cap
Dialogue: You're right. Reckon Saint Peter must be gitten' mighty tired of dustin' off that doormat for him.  By the way, how did you say it happened?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I didn't.

Speaker: cap
Dialogue: Sheriff Jackson it was and one of the Clewses.

Speaker: doc riding
Dialogue: Oh!

Speaker: cap
Dialogue: Tough customers, the Clewses.

Speaker: doc riding
Dialogue: Yeah -- don't pay to start something with 'em you don't intend to finish.

Speaker: cap
Dialogue: That's Bob Clews' brother. Jest done a stretch in pen 'tentiary for horse stealin'.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: They string 'em up for that where I come from.

Speaker: doc riding
Dialogue: Pity they didn't string him up while they wore about it.

Speaker: cap
Dialogue: That's what Arly Harolday was sayin' only this mornin'.  You ain't met our Arly yet, I reckon?

Speaker: doc riding
Dialogue: He will, if he stays here long enough.

Speaker: cap
Dialogue: Hell-fire in skirts.

Speaker: doc riding
Dialogue: Well, here's now.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: What did I tell you? They gotta be big to beat me!

Speaker: cap
Dialogue: Clint Harolday's in luck tonight.

Speaker: doc riding
Dialogue: They're certainly running for him. About time, too. He's taken a beating this last week would shake a better man.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Include me out.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: Aw -- come on. Can't you take it?

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: Not that sort o' luck, I can't. Besides, I on'y came in to oblige.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: Come on, Doc. I still got to take something from you.

Speaker: doc riding
Dialogue: No more tonight, son. I've a full day ahead.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: How about you, sir? Care to sit In? I'm warnin' you, though -- our young friend here has been holding phenomenal cards.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: Have a heart, Judge. This ain't no two-bit saddle-tramp's game. This is for real money.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: Fine! Oh -- this is Pap Fossler; Shorty Davis; Ab Jenkins; Mr. Harolday, and my name's Garvey -- Judge Garvey. I didn't get your name.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I didn't give it.  Deal.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: Raise you twenty.

Speaker: pap
Dialogue: Table stakes, Clint.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: Not if he wants to dig.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: No place for me.

Speaker: pap
Dialogue: Cards?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: One.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: One for me.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Don't you know that Queen is dead?

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: I can take it if I want it.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Sure -- if you want -- but you'll have to beat my hand with four cards.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: I'm playing these, mister!

Speaker: cap
Dialogue: I'm not settin' in.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: Why don't you split the pot?

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: I'm not splitting -- I'm betting!

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: Are you calling?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I'm raising.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Dig.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: Let me have some money

Speaker: pap
Dialogue: You're in deep enough, Clint.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: Full house.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: No good.  Kings up. Your third queen is dead.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: You -- mister -- get away from that table. And get out of here. Maybe from now on you'll know a full house beats two pairs -- four-flusher!

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: No man can run a bluff on me.

Speaker: pap
Dialogue: He wasn't armed.

Speaker: cap
Dialogue: I don't like to tell men how to play cards unless I'm settin' in -- but I mebbe ought to have spoken up.  That Queen was dead, Clint -- and you know it.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: When anybody plays poker with me, they play my game or not at all.

Speaker: cap
Dialogue: You can't just go makin' your own rules, Clint --  -- an' if I was you I'd hightail outa here before he comes back.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: Comes back?

Speaker: cap
Dialogue: He's the kind.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I've come for my money.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: It's all yours, mister -- Cap, there -- Cap is an old gambler -- he says you were right all the time.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: By the way, Judge -- the name is Rocklin.

Speaker: singer's voice
Dialogue: She was only a bird in a gilded cage...

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: How you feelin'?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: After that singin'? -- Thirsty.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: How's your head?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Oh -- a mite hungover -- but I'll feel better once I git downstairs.

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: I knocked, but guess you didn't hear me.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: Looks like you stirred things up around here last night, stranger.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: That all you came to say?

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: No. I got a message for you.  From Old Man Harolday. Wants to see you out front.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: What about?

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: Maybe he wants to thank you for teaching that pup of his a lesson.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I'll be down.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: What's goin' on here?

Speaker: pap fossler
Dialogue: Arly Harolday's on the warpath.

Speaker: ad libs
Dialogue: Here he comes. Watch the fun. This should be good. Etc.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Is your name Rocklin?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: I want that money you took from my brother last night.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Are you crazy? Or just ignorant?

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: -- and I'm taking it back the same way!

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Stop! You! stop, or I'll kill you!

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Turn around.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Whiskey!

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: You lied to me, didn't you?

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Don't think I'll forget this. Making a fool of me in front of the whole town.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Boy, oh boy, was that a near thing! She'd just as soon have hit you as missed. You don't know how lucky you were, son.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Don't I?  Why d'you think I need this?

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: Funniest sight I ever seen.

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: You broke it! You broke it!

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Try another trick like that on me and it'll be worse.

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: I never played you no trick. You broke my wrist.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Oh boy -- has somebody come to town!

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Where'll I find Judge Garvey?

Speaker: cap
Dialogue: He rooms behind his office down the street. Don't usually pull up the blinds till around noon, though.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: See you later, old-timer...

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: Oh, come in, Mr. Rocklin. Come right in.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I understand you were Red Caldwell's lawyer?

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: I was.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Know anything about this?

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: I don't understand. Job? What job?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Foreman.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: But -- but why should he want you?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Why not? Good foremen don't grow on bushes.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: Is that your only motive for coming here?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: What other motive could I have?

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: I don't know -- It's just that Red Caldwell was a peculiar man -- had a funny way of doing things.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: Well, I'm sorry, Mr. Rocklin, that you've been brought all this way on a fool's errand, but -- I'm afraid the deal's off.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Off?

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: I don't want to be too hard on you, but as executor of the estate I have to consider the interests of the new owner. How about, say, a hundred in full settlement?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Well --

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: That's my last word -- think it over.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: How do you do, ladies --

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: You are Judge Garvey, I presume.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: Yes -- and you are --

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Miss Martin -- and my niece, Clara Caldwell.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: Of course -- of course --

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: You came at a very opportune moment, madam. This gentleman claims to have some sort of a letter from the late Mr. Caldwell, engaging him as foreman of the "K.C."

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: What!

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: What do you mean -- claims to have? -- You saw it, didn't you?

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: You can't hold us to account for every promise made by that man. Everyone knows he wasn't responsible for his actions half the time. And if you think I'd have you as a foreman --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Listen, lady -- I'd rather walk for somebody else, than ride for you.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Well -- the impudence --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: All I come for this morning was to pay beck the hundred and fifty Red Caldwell sent in advance.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Oh, no

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Don't interfere, Clara. Of course he must pay it back.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: The railway fare -- well, I reckon we can check that up against the time lost and call it quits.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: But, Mr. -- er -- I don't know your name...

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Rocklin, miss.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Mr. Rocklin, it isn't fair for you to pay anything back.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: That's how I'd prefer it, If you don't mind, miss -- never did care fer owing favors to no one -- especially women.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Oh!

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: I've just heard they let George Clews out of penitentiary and that he's headed this way. You might tell him from me, if he sets foot on the Santee Ranch, I'll shoot him on sight.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: But really, Miss Arly, why should you deliver your message through me?

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: You have mutual friends.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: If you're referring to Sheriff Jackson...

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: I am.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: But that's absurd. The fact that he employs one of the Clews brothers doesn't make the other his friend.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Have it your own way; but it'd be fair to warn him, because I mean it.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: Oh, Miss Caldwell, this is Miss Harolday -- Miss Martin, Miss Caldwell's aunt. You should know one another, seeing you'll be neighbors. Miss Harolday runs the Santee Ranch for her stepfather. She's a famous -- ah -- horsewoman in these parts.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: I know. I saw you ride into town this morning. You looked lovely. Just what I'd like to be.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Oh, this is Mr. Rocklin. He drove us in from Garden City last night. He...

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I already met Miss Harolday.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: I've a message for you -- from Harolday.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: What, again?

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: He wants you to come down to the office.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: What for?

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: He's got a proposition to make -- about riding for him. Sixty a month.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Hmmm -- That's a foreman's wages.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: And the way things are shaping, maybe we could do with somebody as mean as you around the ranch.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: I warn you, you're making a great mistake. This man is no good.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Auntie!

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Well? D'you want the job?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Lead the way.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Auntie, why did you have to say that? I simply don't understand you...

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: I'd be ashamed of myself. Throwing myself at a man like that.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: I... I...  Oh, you're horrid -- horrid. I wish I'd never come.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: You must excuse her. She's young.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: And inexperienced.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: And young people must be protected from themselves at times -- don't you agree?

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: Exactly.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Does he always follow you?

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: He's not following me -- he's with me -- he's always with me.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Oh -- just an old Indian friend.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: The best friend I've got.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Wait here.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: I've just hired a man named Rocklin and said you made me do it. Sixty dollars and he 'll earn it -- while he lasts.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: Why did you do it, Arly?

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: So I can fire him. I hate him. Clint and he quarrelled last night. Clint lied about it and I made a fool of myself.  He's outside now.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: All right. Send him in.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Come in.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: Mr. Rocklin, what happened between you and my son last night?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Poker.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: Hmmm. About this suggestion of you working for me.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: It's your suggestion, not mine.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: Ye-es. Sixty dollars is big money.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: If you've changed your mind...

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: No, no.... Wait a minute. I take it you've had the experience.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Enough for Red Caldwell to hire me as foreman.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: Oh -- had Caldwell hired you?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Yeah -- but I won't ride for the new owners -- so that leaves me open.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: I see -- Were you a friend of Red's?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: No -- I guess he just heard about me.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: George Clews is in town. He's seen what you done to Bob and he's a- lookin' for you.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: The street is clear.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Tell him I'll be out in the street in front of the saloon.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Uh-huh!

Speaker: george clews
Dialogue: I'm gonna get his ears.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Hi you, George Clews --

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Rocklin says if you don't come out, he'll come in here after you, an' tear you apart.

Speaker: shorty
Dialogue: That was my beer, you know.

Speaker: george clews
Dialogue: If he comes in again -- I'll throw you.

Speaker: cap
Dialogue: That does it, boys -- you know where the door is.

Speaker: george clews
Dialogue: Com-mon -- I'll get his ears.

Speaker: cap
Dialogue: Not until I get my money --

Speaker: cap
Dialogue: There's three drinks and a broken beer glass.

Speaker: george clews
Dialogue: Pay 'im.

Speaker: george clews
Dialogue: I'll get his ears.

Speaker: pap
Dialogue: That Rocklin'll kill him for sure.

Speaker: customer
Dialogue: Le's hope.

Speaker: george clews
Dialogue: I'm coming -- and you'd better run!

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Draw a gun and I'll kill you.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Hey, you! What's this you been up to?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I just laid a gun barrel over the head of a drunk friend of yours -- same as you did over Dave's here yesterday.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Eh?

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: I don't know what you're talking about.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: You're a liar!

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Now you lookee here, young feller. You go on talking that way and you'll find yourself in trouble.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Don't say you ain't been warned.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: I saw you. I saw you strike that poor man.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am. As hard as I could.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: You ruffian, you!

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Let me go!  I knew the sort you were the moment I set eyes on you. You can't fool me! You're nothing but a common adventurer! Come, Clara!

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: -- Now what was that you were sayin' about Caldwell?

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: You being hired by Red Caldwell only confirms what I'd suspected -- he was getting ready to fight.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Fight? Who?

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: Organized rustling. Well at least -- that's my belief. Red was no friend of mine. Too fond of taking the law into his own hands. But he had my sympathy. He'd been harder hit than any of us. And on top of it all, he lost his foreman.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: You mean, he quit on him?

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: He was shot -- in the back -- with a bullet from the same caliber rifle as got Red.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Got any ideas?

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: No -- Except that the man you just pistol-whipped is in on it somewhere.  Pity you didn't kill him when you had the chance.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Say -- it don't sound as if it's goin' to be too easy for them wimmen at the K.C.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: Want to go back and work for them?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: No, sir. And I ain't jumping at this offer o' yours either because I don't hold with working for wimmen.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: Oh, you mean my step-daughter. Well don't worry. She won't interfere with you...Rocklin -- I figure we've been losin' cattle over a place called Table Top -- it's the back way into the Topaz Ranch and the perfect route for rustlers -- I'm going to send you up to the line camp -- you don't mind working a lone hand -- do you?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: -- I like workin' that way.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: Good -- be ready to move out this afternoon.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: -- now Pap -- I'm givin' you first call on me services. They's lots of other folks lookin' fer a good man, too -- you know. So if you want me, you better hurry and speak up because --

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: 'scuse me, Pap -- Be right back to find out when I start.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Whar you off to?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I'm riding for the Topaz Ranch.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: What! -- Have you gone plumb loco?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Good money -- sixty a month

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: There ain't enough money in this town to make it worth your while to work for that gal.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: When she gits goin' she can be meaner'n a skillet full o' snakes. She ain't goin' to forget the way you made a fool of her today -- in front of the whole town.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Be right with you.  It's pizen that's what it is -- jus' plain --- What you want to hang around this town for anyways? --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Be right with you.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Good afternoon, Mr. Rocklin.  Lovely day, isn't it?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Reckon it is pretty nice. So you're moving in on the "K.C." eh?

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: We-el, not exactly moving in. You see...

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Do you have to discuss our private affairs with every rag-tag-and-bobtail cow-person we meet, Clara?

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Auntie!

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Sorry if I butted in, ma'am. Jest passing the time o'day.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: We can do very well without it -- thank you.  And you're keeping your lady friend waiting.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: I thought maybe you'd changed your mind again.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Nope.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Juan'll show you the bunkhouse. I'll talk to you about your duties in the morning.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: How far is the line-camp at Table- Top?

Speaker: juan
Dialogue: Twenty-five -- thirty mile.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I'm moving out there first thing in the morning.  Boss' orders. Care to show me the way?

Speaker: juan
Dialogue: I will show you.

Speaker: juan
Dialogue: Adios, Senor.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Senor Romerez, it appears that you do not like me.

Speaker: juan
Dialogue: Senor, that is true. I do not like you.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: juan
Dialogue: Permit that I offer you a cigarette.

Speaker: juan
Dialogue: It is not your fault that your shadow is black. But you will only bring unhappiness to my senorita. I do not blame you, but I fear I must hate you.

Speaker: juan
Dialogue: Adios, Senor.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Hiya there.

Speaker: juan
Dialogue: Buenos dias, Senor Dave.  You have found new employer, eh?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Yeah. Haulin' freight for ole Pap Fossler. Got a letter here for that crazy galoot, Rocklin.

Speaker: juan
Dialogue: But Senor Rocklin is not here.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Lordy -- he ain't quit already...

Speaker: juan
Dialogue: I have just accompany him to Table- Top.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: Have you seen Arly?

Speaker: shelley
Dialogue: No, suh, Ah didn't see Miss Arly today, but Ah seed her las' night, and she shore was mad.

Speaker: shelley
Dialogue: Plenty mad!

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: 'Mornin', Arly --

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: 'Mornin', Clint.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: You must be feeling pretty good.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: Say, Arly -- about that poker game, night before last, I ---

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Forget it.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: Forget it?

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Tala.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Well --

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: What is this? --

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: What do I mean? --

Speaker: tala's voice
Dialogue: Good morning, Arliete.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Good morning, Tala.

Speaker: tala
Dialogue: You have make yourself very pretty today.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: See what I mean?

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Have my horse saddled and sent around right away -- will you?  You can have that Rocklin bring it.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: What's the matter?

Speaker: tala
Dialogue: Rocklin is not here.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: He quit?

Speaker: tala
Dialogue: He has gone to the line camp at Table Top.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: tala
Dialogue: It was Mr. Harolday's orders.

Speaker: tala
Dialogue: Why do you make your heart heavy with thoughts of him, little one. -- He is not for you.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Be quiet.

Speaker: tala
Dialogue: He has made the choice, Arliete. With your own eyes you saw it yesterday.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Oh --

Speaker: tala
Dialogue: And she, too, has opened her heart to him -- Already she has summoned him to her.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: tala
Dialogue: Dave -- of the white beard -- carries a letter to Rocklin -- It is from her.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: How do you know that?

Speaker: tala
Dialogue: I have just now met Dave, and he tell me. -- So now he rides to Table Top.

Speaker: tala
Dialogue: Little one you --

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Oh, leave me alone.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: Good morning, Julio -- morning Arly.  Fetch my briefcase -- it's on my desk.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: Looks like we're going to get that land we've been wanting along the river bottom.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: I didn't tell you -- but I bought the mortgage on the Hardman ranch, and it's due today -- On my way over there now.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Did you send that Rocklin to Table- Top?

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: I did.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Well, let's get things straight. This place was my mother's -- now it's mine and Clint's -- It's true you've been helping out -- but the way things are going we'll soon be able to pay you back every penny we owe. Meanwhile, I'm running this outfit and I expect to give the orders.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: You generally do.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Why did you send Rocklin up to Table- Top?

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: It seemed to me a good idea -- what with all this rustling going on --

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Who'd ever try driving cattle over Table-Top? -- Unless they were crazy.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: I don't agree with you. In any case -- if you must have it -- I'd no intention of engaging a man at foreman's wages just to gratify the whims of a jealous woman!

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: You take care what you're saying.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: It's you should take care, my dear. I'm afraid there's one man you can't rawhide into jumping the way you want. You've made a fool of yourself over him once. Better watch out you don't do it again.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Durn funny -- that storm quittin' just about the time I get here.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: No funnier than you sloggin' through it, just to deliver a letter from a woman.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Reckon I'm gettin' to be more of a fool the older I get.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: When are we gonna get around to readin' it?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Thought I'd wait till mornin' -- might be bad news an' I wouldn't be able to sleep.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Mmmm -- dineroo.

Speaker: rocklin's voice
Dialogue: Forgive me if this letter is a trifle incoherent, but I am terribly worried and unhappy.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Who wouldn't be -- livin' with that ole screech owl.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I am desperately in need of help and advice from someone whom I feel I can trust, and I am appealing to you, because I regard you in the same way my Uncle surely must have. I heartily dislike and distrust Judge Garvey --

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Huh -- Smart girl --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: But my Aunt seems to have suddenly revised her opinion of him, and now wants me to place all my affairs in the Judge's hands and return east. Such is certainly not my wish.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Looks kinda like she's formed an attachment.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: For the locality, I mean.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I wanted so much to give ranch life a trial, but fear circumstances are against me, especially in view of the recent Indian trouble --

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Good Lord, they ain't been any Indian trouble around here in --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: You want to hear the rest of this?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Might's well -- come this far.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I want to apologize for what took place this afternoon. And I am returning the 150, because I feel it is rightfully yours. You must take it. Faithfully yours, Clara Caldwell.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Well -- what do you make of it?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Somebody's sure bustin' to get her out of there.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Indian trouble --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Wonder why the old lady's playin' along?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Got to admit though, I feel a mite sorry for the young'un -- nice little tyke.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Too nice for this country.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: She's shore a pretty thing.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Don't know how I could help her -- even if I wanted to -- I don't know any thing about this Garvey -- or Caldwell -- or --

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Well, now -- I could mebbe help you out some, there -- Fact, I could tell you somethin' 'bout ole Red that might be interestin'.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: You must have known him pretty well -- What kind of a man was he?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Caldwell? -- The best -- cantankerous cuss -- but a real cowman, believe me -- He was a big feller, like yourself -- Fact, you coulda passed fer a blood relation, come to think of it.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Was the Judge and Red friends?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: That's what you'd say. Garvey managed all Red's business. Besides which they was regular drinkin' pals -- played poker together most nights -- tho' they do say Red got the worst of it.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Red was a gambler, eh?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Oh, yeah -- reckon a pretty poor one, tho' -- still you'd say him and Garvey was friends.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Anything ever happen to make you think they weren't?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Rock -- I'm gonna tell you somethin' I ain't never told anybody.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Think you can trust me?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: The last time I seen Red was the day he died --

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: -- 'Twas in town -- he jus' come out of the stage office. Tried to book passage to Garden City but couldn't on account I had a full load. -- Well, sir, he took me aside and give me a printed sheet of paper and says, "Read it." I looked it over and fer as I could see it was a paper from one of them Chicago sportin' firms, tellin' how to manipulate trick playin' cards.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Marked cards.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Reckon so. -- Seems Red found some cards and this paper in a coat one of his friends loaned him one night.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Whose was it?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Well, now that's just what I asked -- but all he said, was that it belonged to a good friend. Then he said he wasn't waitin' fer the next coach, but was ridin' over to see the district judge about it alone.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: That's when they got him.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Yes, sir -- 'bout a mile or so from Stan's place. A bullet in the back an' his pockets empty.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: How come you never told this before?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Who was there to tell? -- Sheriff Jackson? -- Him an' Garvey's thick as thieves.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: How about what's his name -- Harolday? -- He's no friend of the Judge's, is he?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Hates his guts -- sure riles him to see young Clint hangin' onto the Judge's coattails. All the same, I jus' decided to keep my mouth shut and my eyes open.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Even if it was Garvey Red was talkin' about -- it don't follow that he killed him.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: No -- general opinion is that it was rustlers.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Why would rustlers take the evidence Caldwell had with him?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Looks to me if you get the man who owned the marked cards, you get the killer.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Funny tho' -- first the K.C. foreman -- then Caldwell -- an' now these women.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Lordy -- you ain't thinkin' somebody might try bumpin' them?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Remember, when we stopped to change horses on the way Over from Garden City --

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Shore -- you told me how Jackson and Clews tried to frame Stan.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Yeah. Like they wanted to be sure he'd keep his mouth shut about something.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: And layin' that gun across my skull -- an' offerin' to drive the coach themselves.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: It was almost as if --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: You all right?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Will be if I ever get dry.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Lookit that --

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Good Lord --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Come on --

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: My team.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: That's not your team.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Come on --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: No use -- he's gone.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Mebbe we winged him.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Not bad shootin'.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: You think I did that?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Sure -- to draw us away from here.  You know, you cut it mighty close -- Good thing I ain't got brains enough to fill it.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Too bad you had to come 'way up here through that storm for nothin'.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: -- because I came up to fire you.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Oh --  I see.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Get out of here -- get off the Santee and don't ever come back.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Mind if I wait for Dave? He ought to be along any minute -- Be funny if he winged that shadow of yours.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: If you mean Juan -- you're loco. He's not even up here.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: You came up alone?

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Then who was that we took out after?

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: The man who shot at you.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Who was he?

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: You mean you won't tell.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: I mean I don't know -- Why should I lie to you?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I guess you forgot -- you jes' fired me.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: So long.

Speaker: dave's voice
Dialogue: Hey, Rock --

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: -- He got away -- but guess what, I --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: You guess --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Come on.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Fer a man who's got a despise fer wimmin, you sure do get all snaggled up with 'em.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: You work for Harolday?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Here's one of his horses -- I'll pick up my saddle later.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Howdy...

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: I thought I sent you up to Table- Top.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Well, this, for one thing.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: I told you you'd regret letting that rat Clews off so easy.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: What's the matter? Don't you think it was him, then?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I been figgerin'. Don't seem reasonable Clews was in condition to take that sort of chance alone... Besides -- how could he have known I was up there -- that soon. And -- George Clews ain't the only one I've run contrariwise to in this town. There's that Mexican, for instance.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: Juan?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: He as good as told me yesterday that him and me was due for a run-in one of those days.  And then there's him!

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Was what?

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: Was shot at last night.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: Any idea who might have done it?

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: Not me.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: You ain't trying to pin it on me?  'Cause if you are, you're in for a big disappointment. I was over at the Sun-Up playing poker with the Judge and the rest of the boys till early morning. If you don't believe me, ask for yourself.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: All right. I believe you. But that don't mean you couldn't tell a thing or two as would help -- if you wanted.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: What d'you mean?

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: Yes. What sort of thing would Clint here know about, that would help identify the man who tried to kill you last night?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: This for one.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Ever seen it before?

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: Well, go on -- speak up. Did you ever see it before?

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: Quit riding me! I don't know nothin' about it I tell you. Jest because I had a run-in with you over a game o' cards, that don't mean I'd sneak up on you in the dark and...

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: He means trouble.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: Aw, what do I care.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: Listen, I never did have much use for you. You're a poor specimen at the best; but as a would-be bad man you're nothing but a laughing stock. Why, the way you lied about that pouch just now wouldn't have deceived a six-year old.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: You'll find some money in the safe at the ranch. Take what you need and put the key in the desk drawer. Now get.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Oh, Mr. Rocklin --

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: I'm so glad I've found you -- I was on my way to the Santee and learned you were in town.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Just got in.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: I feel perfectly awful, running after you like this, but --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: You got trouble, eh?

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: My aunt found out I wrote you and made a terrible scene --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: You haven't signed everything over to that Garvey, have you?

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: No -- and because I refused, Auntie said she would sign an affidavit that I'm still underage, and then, as my guardian she can do what she likes.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Got anything to prove you're not underage?

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: No -- but Mr. Garvey has a letter that would prove it. My aunt wrote it before we came out here.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: S'pose we could get it?

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: He'd never give it to me.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Wait here.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: You won't go getting yourself in trouble -- I -- I'd rather give up everything -- I mean --

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: That takes care of that --  Now, I'll draw up an affidavit right away and everything will be taken care of as we want it.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: I certainly hope so -- it's not myself I'm concerned about --

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: -- Of course not.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: I can't say I'm very happy about doing this -- I only hope it works out for the best.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: It's the better choice of two evils -- now let's see --  It is Elizabeth, isn't it?

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Yes --

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: -- Elizabeth Martin, of Danvers, Massachusetts, do hereby --

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: Well, Mr. Rocklin, this is indeed a surprise. Didn't expect to see you so soon. I understood you were riding for the Santee.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: Perhaps you'd better come back later --

Speaker: rocklin's voice
Dialogue: I came for that letter.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: Did you say letter?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: That's right -- the one Miss Caldwell's aunt wrote from out east sayin' she was of age. Remember?

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: No -- I'm afraid I don't.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: What is your interest in this letter?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: My only interest is getting' it.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: You realize what this is, don't you? -- Robbing -- armed robbery at that.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: I warn you, you're in for a disappointment.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Open up.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: There's nothing in there that'd interest you.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I'd like to make up my own mind about that.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: All right -- I'll open it -- just to convince you I'm not hiding any letter.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: What's the idea?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: These cards --

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: Anything wrong in a man having cards in his possession?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Depends on what kind they are -- 'specially when they're under lock and key.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: You're taking those, I presume.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: Now, you look here --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: You're the one who better start lookin' -- lookin' for a way out for killin' Red Caldwell.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: Caldwell --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: He found out about these -- and you went and killed him.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: And you believe a story like that?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I will until I hear a better one.  I'll just take this along -- the district judge at Garden City should be mighty interested.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Say -- looks like you two been disagreein' 'bout somethin' --  He ain't daid, is he?

Speaker: pap fossler
Dialogue: Not permanently, I don't reckon. -- What happened, anyways?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: You musta found out somethin'.

Speaker: pap fossler
Dialogue: I reckon the Judge did, too.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Oh, dear -- dear -- are you hurt?

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: Get out of my way --

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: I'll have you understand I --

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: -- Find out who owns that tobaccy pouch yet?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: No -- but get hold of Clint Harolday.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Clint -- Is he in on it?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Can't say for sure -- Bring him to the Sun-Up, and don't take no for an answer.

Speaker: arly's voice
Dialogue: -- So now you know the truth. And if you think you can steal him away from me, you're welcome to try it.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Did you get it?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: No -- but I don't think it's gonna matter much -- you go on back to the K.C. and I'll be out in the mornin' and take you with me to Garden City to see the district judge.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: But I hate putting you to that trouble.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: No trouble at all -- I'm going anyway.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: You look like you've been fighting.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: What are you doin' here?

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: I was just telling Miss Caldwell about -- well -- you and me.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: What about, you an' me?

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: I think I'd better be going...

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: What all has she been tellin' you?

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Oh -- oh, really I'd rather not --

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: -- and I dare him to deny it.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Deny what?

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: That she was with you last night at the cabin in the mountains.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Well -- why should I deny it?...

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: And didn't you make love to me?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Make love to you --

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: You didn't kiss me -- I suppose?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Did you expect me to deny that, too?

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: You see?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Now, maybe you ought to hear what I've got to say --

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Please -- you needn't explain. After all, it really isn't any of my business, is it?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: You little --

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Just like a man.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: If there wasn't a lady here, I'd do more to you than swear.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: I don't know how I can ever thank you for trying to help me. I do appreciate it ever so much --  Don't think too harshly of me, will you -- I --

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: She's lovely, isn't she? -- So sweet -- honest, and helpless.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Pity you didn't fall in love with her, instead of me.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: You might's well know right now that you or no woman is ever goin' to get me.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Don't be so sure -- I don't think I'm doin' so badly.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Don't you?

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Don't you know?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I know there ain't a dirty trick you wouldn't play to get what you want.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: I always get what I want.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: -- See?  -- 'Bye now --

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Whatever is to become of you?

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Have you no sense of pride, or decency? Throwing yourself at that -- that wretch, like any shameless hussy.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: I thought we'd done with him -- but no -- you have to run to him and tell him all our business --

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Don't you dare deny it -- you know very well you told him about that letter I wrote Mr. Garvey.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Didn't you? --

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Didn't you?

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: Tell Miss Martin that I'll take care of everything.

Speaker: sammy
Dialogue: -- You take clare of evelything.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Come in --

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Here he is, Rock. Caught him jist in time near the Santee. Headed fer out, I'd say.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Sit down, Clint.  How about goin' down below an' havin' one on me?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Well, now -- that's right thoughtful -- Holler if you need me.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: What's this all about?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: It ain't gonna do you any good to get all het up and tough, kid --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I just want to ask you a few questions -- that's all.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: I told you once, I don't know who owns that pouch-- and I don't know who shot you.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Forget it -- that's not what I want to talk to you about, anyway.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: Well, what do you want to talk about? Come on, get it over with.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Clint -- I want you to tell me why Garvey murdered Red Caldwell --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: You know -- don't you?

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: Me? No!

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Oh yes you do.  And you're going to tell me all about it.

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: I don't know nothing, I tell you -- I --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Talk!

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: I tell ya, I...

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Talk!

Speaker: clint
Dialogue: No! No, don't!

Speaker: ad libs
Dialogue: What happened? Who is it? Clint Harolday -- Etc.

Speaker: pap fossler
Dialogue: Where's Doc Riding?

Speaker: ad libs
Dialogue: Get the Doc. Hey, Doc -- He was down below. Here he is.

Speaker: ad libs
Dialogue: Look out, men -- Let the Doc through. Etc.

Speaker: doc riding
Dialogue: Somebody better fetch Harolday.

Speaker: cap
Dialogue: Shorty's already gone for him.

Speaker: pap fossler
Dialogue: Better get Arly, too.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: She was at the hotel a while ago.

Speaker: pap fossler
Dialogue: He was only a kid.

Speaker: jackson's voice
Dialogue: What's goin' on here -- gang way --

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: What's the trouble here --

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Hand over that gun.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Just a minute, now --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I know it looks bad -- but I didn't kill the kid.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: I believe you.  His gun was layin' over there on the floor when I come in and --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: No it wasn't -- It was right in my hand -- like it is now.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: If you didn't know him -- then who did?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I don't know --  But I'm going to find out.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: Where is he? -- Where's my boy?

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: You murderer.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I didn't do it, Mr. Harolday.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: Then who did?

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: He had a gun in his hand when we come in.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: And I'll bet it's the same one the bullet that killed Clint came out of.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: Well, what do you say to that?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: He's right.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: You admit it.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Yeah -- but that still don't say I killed him.

Speaker: ad libs
Dialogue: Aw, take him away -- Liar -- Lock him up, Sheriff -- The yellow-bellied -- Etc.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Why did you do it?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I didn't.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: He admits it was his gun that shot him.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: But you didn't fire it.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Clint and me was having a bit of an argument.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: What about?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: For instance -- who it was shot Red Caldwell.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Caldwell!

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: And the K.C. foreman. And who took that shot at me up at Table-Top last night. And why certain people are so anxious to get rid of the Caldwell girl.

Speaker: pap fossler
Dialogue: How would Clint know about all that?

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: He's lying. He's trying to cover up for killing my boy.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Quit stalling, Rocklin.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Wait a minute -- he's get a right to be heard.  Well, we're listenin'.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Well -- Clint was getting' all set to talk, when -- somebody snuck up along the verandah there and pulled the gun out o' my belt...  ... and let him have it.

Speaker: ad libs
Dialogue: What a story! What an alibi! String him up, the heel! Etc.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: You'll have to think up something better than that Rocklin.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: Don't be a fool, Rocklin. You know you can't get away with a yarn like that. Why don't you save yourself and everyone else a lot of trouble by surrendering to the Sheriff? After all, it isn't such a crime in these parts to kill a man in self-defense.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Self-defense?

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: Everyone knows what Clint was like. He probably lost his head and pulled a gun on you, like he did at the Sun- Up that night. Wasn't that it?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: If I got to be shot for knowing too much, it ain't going to be in the back, in a framed-up jail-break.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: But if someone's trying to kill you, why didn't they do it just now? Why did they have to kill Clint?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Guess they wanted to get Clint, too. Doin' it this way they get us both. Clint first -- an' me afterwards -- like I jus' said.

Speaker: pap fossler
Dialogue: Quit fancy talk. Who's "they?"

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I might be able to tell you that later.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: No you won't -- because you're comin' with me.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Am I?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: The first one that moves -- gets it.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: Well, Sheriff -- you certainly are to be congratulated.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Look, Mr. Harolday -- you saw what happened --

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: Never mind that -- Let's get going for Garden City -- that's where he's headed for.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: You sure?

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: I'm positive.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Where do you think he's gone?

Speaker: jackson's voice
Dialogue: All right, men -- follow me --

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: I mighta knowed you'd do somethin' like this.  What are we doin'?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Headin' for the K.C.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Now -- what is it?

Speaker: george clews
Dialogue: The name's Clews, ma'am -- Mr. Garvey sent us out --

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: Said you were expectin' trouble with that Rocklin.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: I am.  -- But I'm wondering if you're up to it. I noticed you didn't fare so well with him yesterday.

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: He was drunk --

Speaker: george clews
Dialogue: Yeah -- But I'm sober now.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Well, see that you stay that way.

Speaker: george clews
Dialogue: Don't worry, ma'am -- I've jus' bin waitin' to get even with that saddle- bum.

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: We'll be close-by.

Speaker: george clews
Dialogue: You bet.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Seen anybody ridin' hard for Garden City.

Speaker: zeke
Dialogue: Bin on the road since sundown -- ain't seen a livin' soul -- be he man or beast.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: He mighta taken the cutoff through Jaw Bone Canyon.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: After that storm? -- He'd never make it.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: There's only one other place he might have gone -- the K.C.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: You think so?

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: I'm positive.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: That's what you said before.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: To the K.C., men.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Take me through the canyon.

Speaker: juan
Dialogue: It is dangerous, senorita.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: But if we get through we'll beat them to the K.C.

Speaker: juan
Dialogue: You would risk your life for Senor Rocklin?

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Afraid?

Speaker: julio
Dialogue: Only for you -- you must not do this -- I will go through from here alone.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: No, -- we're going through together.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: You can ease up now.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: We're just about there.

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: Hey, George -- George, get up.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: You vile, ungrateful strumpet -- running away in the night, like a deceitful sneak-thief --

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Yes -- I'm running away -- and it's all your fault -- you're the one who's been deceitful and sneaking -- and don't think I don't know what you intend doing.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: -- And don't think I don't know what you intend doing.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: I don't care -- I'm not ashamed of it -- and nothing you can say or do is going to stop me.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: You little fool -- if you go to Garden City with that man -- you stand to lose everything.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: But why? -- Why are you being so secretive? -- If you know something, why don't you tell me?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Yeah -- why don't you? --

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: All right, I'll tell you -- Rocklin is a nephew of the late Mr. Caldwell. And, as nearest of kin, he stands to get everything -- according to the will. Because you are not the old man's niece, but only his grand-niece.

Speaker: clara's voice
Dialogue: And you and Mr. Garvey knew the truth all the time?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: -- And you knew the truth all the time, too -- didn't you? -- No wonder you stuck around --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Get in here and take care of her.

Speaker: george clews
Dialogue: Come on --

Speaker: julio
Dialogue: You are crying, senorita --?

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: julio
Dialogue: It is too bad we lose your horse. She was good horse, for sure.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: If only we make it in time.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: -- And I heard one of them tell my aunt not to worry, that he was just as anxious as she was to get even with you.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: This is the only way I could handle her.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: The Clews are around here some place -- Garvey sent 'em out.

Speaker: george clews
Dialogue: You bet we're around.

Speaker: george clews
Dialogue: Untie her.

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: Untie her.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: I'll take part in this -- you -- you hairy beast.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Help me get her to the bed.

Speaker: george clews
Dialogue: What'll we do with 'em?

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Take them in to Mr. Garvey and tell him I must see him at once.

Speaker: bob clews
Dialogue: We'll dump them right in the Judge's lap.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Hadn't you better tie him, too?

Speaker: george clews
Dialogue: Get some more rope.

Speaker: george clews
Dialogue: Get our horses and meet me at the gate.

Speaker: george clews
Dialogue: What are you doin' with that gun, Arly?

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Get down from there before I show you.

Speaker: arly's voice
Dialogue: Neither is it yours -- Get down out of there -- before I knock you down.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: -- And they're headed this way and should get here any minute --

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Where'd you get this?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: That belongs to the man who shot at me on Table-Top -- Dave found it.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: You've got to get away -- they'll be here -- they'll catch you --

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: You've got to stop him -- he's got to get away.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Come on -- let's git goin' --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Where's the girl?

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Back at the house --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: We've got to get her.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: You haven't time -- they're coming -- don't you believe me? --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Come on --

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: You're puttin' a rope around your neck --

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Get him --  -- out of sight, and follow me.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: But what'll we do with the ole lady?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Anything you like.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: I'd like to pizen her.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Look.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Come on.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: If you'll just take this -- you'll go to sleep --

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Evenin' ma'am -- hate to bother you like this, but --

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: -- Why -- what are all these people doing here?

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: We're after Rocklin -- has he been here?

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Oh yes -- here and gone.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: What!

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: Gone --

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Yes -- the two men you sent out are taking him and that horrid old man back to town.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: The Clewses -- funny we didn't see them.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: Somethin' musta gone wrong -- We better fan out and see what's goin' on.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Don't leave, Mr. Garvey -- I've got to talk with you, privately --

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: But, madam --

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: It's very important.

Speaker: harolday
Dialogue: We'll go on and meet you in town.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: Perhaps you'd better.  I'll meet you in town, Jackson.

Speaker: jackson's voice
Dialogue: Right -- come on, men.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: -- And you're positive he knows everything?

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Absolutely everything -- He was standing at the window all the time -- the scoundrel.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: You better get back on the bed -- in case they come in here.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: If you were to ask me, I think the best thing to do is --

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: I'm not asking you -- and don't bother me with your silly questions -- we've got to do something besides talk.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: You mean -- you have to do something.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: -- This was all your idea, remember.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: My idea -- that's all you know about it.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: If there's anybody else in on it -- speak up, Judge.

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: Well -- I do declare --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Talk.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Not you.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Ever see that before?

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: No -- it's not mine.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Tell me whose it is.

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: No -- no -- I don't know --

Speaker: arly's voice
Dialogue: Drop that gun.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: He was just getting ready to finish you off, through that window.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: You seem to like to do business through windows, Mr. Harolday.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: You're not Clint's killer, by any chance --

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: Juan saw you do it.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Well, now we're gettin' some place --

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: That pouch is his --  Didn't you?

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Why did you kill Caldwell?

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: -- Harolday wanted the K.C. like he wanted the Santee and the Hardman place, for his land scheme -- He planned on breaking up the ranches into small holdings and selling to dirt farmers. He pretended to be on the outs with me so I could get Caldwell's confidence. And when Red caught me with the crooked cards and threatened to expose me -- Harolday shot him.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: Why did he kill Clint? An' not me?

Speaker: garvey
Dialogue: That shot was an accident -- it was meant for you. We planned on getting the women to let me handle their business --

Speaker: miss martin
Dialogue: You vile -- wicked -- despicable --

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: When he wakes up -- we'll have him put everything on paper.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: Well, you'll have to do the writin' -- 'cause I don't know how to write.

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: Oh, Mr. Rocklin -- please -- I think Auntie is out of her mind -- she's in her room -- laughing.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: What that ole pelican needs is a good spankin'.

Speaker: arly
Dialogue: And I'll bet you're just the one who can do it.

Speaker: dave
Dialogue: I know I am.

Speaker: rocklin
Dialogue: I guess there's no rush for you to get to Garden City, now --

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: No -- I don't suppose there's any -- rush --

Speaker: clara
Dialogue: If I was like her, I'd stay in the West.
